title: 107_hr120
content: The "Social Security and Medicare Lockbox Act of 2001" aims to prioritize the solvency of social security and Medicare by prohibiting the use of their surpluses for any other purpose than paying down debt until legislation is passed to extend their solvency. The amendment to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 reserves surpluses until social security and Medicare solvency legislation is enacted, prohibiting the use of surpluses for any other purpose. The amendment to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 reserves baseline budget surpluses until social security and Medicare solvency legislation is enacted, prohibiting their use for any other purpose. The baseline budget projection includes current year levels of outlays, receipts, and surplus or deficit for future years, with discretionary appropriations subject to limits. Surpluses are reserved until social security and Medicare solvency legislation is enacted. The baseline budget surpluses are used if legislation affecting revenues or direct spending does not offset reductions or increases, respectively. Appropriations bills must adhere to these guidelines. The term 'social security solvency certification' refers to a certification by the Board of Trustees of the Social Security Trust Funds that the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund are in actuarial balance for a 75-year period. The curr_chunk discusses the Medicare solvency certification and the Super Majority Requirement amendments to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. It defines Medicare solvency certification as a certification by the Board of Trustees of the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund. The Super Majority Requirement amendments involve inserting "312(g)," after "310(d)(2),". SEC. 4. EFFECTIVE DATE: This Act will be effective upon enactment and will apply to fiscal year 2001 and beyond.
